results.title: This is Robert
results.creator_credit: L. Joseph Stone, Mary S. Fisher and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Vassar studies: studies of normal personality development”
This film traces the development of an aggressive, “difficult” yet thoroughly appealing child from his early nursery days to his first year at a public school. Clumsy, blundering, confused by varied adult pressures, Robert’s violent and haphazard aggression is seen as a strong, defensive counter-attack on the whole world. His mother’s steadying support and his teachers’ firm consistent and affectionate treatment bring him safely through the first adolescence of the pre-school years to an outwardly smooth adjustment in public school, without his earlier inflammable outbursts.
results.creator_credit_for_label: L. Joseph Stone, Mary S. Fisher and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study

results.title: This is not Einstein
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, La Compagnie des Taxi-Brousse, Arte France, Eric Michel, Arnaud Hantute and Catherine Fol
results.brief_description: Can world problems be solved by mathematical equations alone? This contemplative work ponders the marvels of the Universe and other scientific questions by engaging the viewer as if the curiosity and wonder of a child are re-lived through adult eyes. A woman investigates the writings of Albert Einstein and interviews contemporary physicists in a bid to answer some of her musings on his enlightened words. Einstein’s written words are given voice by way of a gentle narration as our protagonist pours over old photos of him and uses white gloves to hold his original papers. Declares Einstein: “..imagination is more important than knowledge..” and this imaginative docu-drama really could ignite the enthusiasm of a young person (or one young at heart) to contemplate the scientific realm. Features Dr Trinh Xuan Thuan and Dr Francoise Balibar with actress Pascale Montpetit as the woman.

results.title: This is not Beirut
results.brief_description: Experimental in its format, “This is not Beirut” is a wonderful documentary comprising of an eclectic mix of film footage from Hi-8, VHS and “found” film material shot and collected in Lebanon during 1992. Filmmaker Jayce Salloum took on the challenge of selecting from over 200 hours of film footage to produce a unique and intriguing piece of film journalism which focuses mainly on Beirut, a city sometimes called the “City of eternity”, “Jewel of the Levant”, or “Window on the West” or conversely the “City in crisis”, “City of fear”, or “Improbable city”. By putting together a montage of these images Salloum provides an insight into Beirut and Lebanon, the constant reconstruction, structually and mentally, from years of bombings, kidnappings, killings, internal warfare, terrorists, resistance movements, and Israeli aggression and invasion. Enhancing this constantly changing stream of images is a soundtrack of interviews, conversations and commentary, television and radio broadcasts, street noises, music and even the occasional silent piece of footage. Salloum attempts to represent Lebanon and the Lebanese people as they see themselves and not necessarily as the West sees them, a concept which proves to be more difficult and problematical than expected. Historically interesting and a most enlightening documentary.

results.title: This is no time for romance
results.brief_description: Idle hours at a summer cottage, when her husband is at work and the children busy at play, give a wife time to dream a little and reflect on her life and her marriage. Is it enough? What else might she have made of herself? But then her husband returns and she opts for things as they are. A relaxed drama that has much of the mood of a summer outdoors. Cast includes Marc Favreau and Monique Mercure. (Awards: Tours; Toronto.)
